page.title: 03FISHING AT LA ROCQUE
page.content: Steven Robinson's grandad has been a fisherman all his life. He has seen many changes around La Rocque. Fishermen don't now go off for a whole week to the Minquiers. Lobster pots are now made out of metal whereas they used to be made out of green willow. In 1940 fishermen used cotton nets but now nets are made from monofil, a man-made fibre. Boats were made from wood, now they're more usually made from fibreglass and are equipped with motors instead of oars. In pre-war days if a fisherman saw another's nets he would move somewhere else. Nowadays, they put their nets down right next to someone else's. In those days, you could leave your nets on the slipway for a week to dry out. Today, you would find they had been taken.
